position.marginalia_text: Plaerunq[ue] unius anni consulatu, plus gestum seriorum negotiorum, egregiorumq[ue] facinorum, quam tota vita maximorum Regum: exceptis admodum paucis; Cyro, Philippo, Alexandro, Pyrrho; Agesilao, Evagora, Eumene; Jugurtha, Mithridate: aliis perpaucis. Olim plus virtutis, minus famae: hodie plus famae, minus virtutis. Egregie Romanus Poeta, ex ipsius Caesaris disciplina: breve, et irreparabile tempus, Omnibus est vitae: sed Famam extendere Factis, Hoc Virtutis opus.

marginalia.translation: In a consulate of one year generally more serious business and excellent deeds are accomplished than in the entire life of the greatest kings, with very few exceptions: Cyrus, Philip, Alexander, Pyrrhus, Agesilaus, Evagoras, Eumenes, Jugurtha, Mithridates, and extremely few others. Once there was more virtue, less fame; today there is more fame, less virtue. Based on the discipline of Caesar himself, the Roman poet put it brilliantly: “the course of life is brief and cannot be recalled: but virtue’s task is this, to increase fame by deeds” [Aeneid 10.467, trans. Kline].

position.marginalia_text: Scire GrÆcÀ, Romanaeq[ue] historiÆ continuatam seriem, valde conducit polyhistori. Herodotus historiam suam est orsus a fine prophetarum: Thucydides a fine Herodoti: Xenophon a fine Thucydidis. Romanae historiae primam partem praecipue suscepit Halicarnasseus; professus eam se historiam velle producere usq[ue] ad initium primi belli Punici. Secundam partem antea suscepit Polybius. Postea Livius tertiam potissimum partem explicare voluit. Tacitus non procul a fine Livii suos Annales orditur: Marcellinus a fine Taciti, id est, a principatu Nervae: ut Herodianus ab exitu M. Antonini, in quo desiit Dion. Nec est difficile, talia continuae successionis exempla in aliis plaerisq[ue] historicis observare.

marginalia.translation: It is tremendously profitable for the polyhistor to know the continuous line of Greek and Roman history. Herodotus began his history from the end of the prophets; Thucydides from the end of Herodotus; Xenophon from the end of Thucydides. Dionysius of Halicarnassus took up the first part of Roman history in particular, declaring he wanted to record history up to the beginning of the first Punic war. Before, Polybius took on the second part. Afterwards Livy wanted to give an account of the third part especially. Tacitus begins his Annals not far from the end of Livy. Marcellinus from the end of Tacitus, namely from the principate of Nerva, just as Herodian starts from the death of Marcus Antoninus, where Cassius Dio stopped. And it is not hard to notice such examples of continued succession in most of the other historians.

position.marginalia_text: Duo autem RomanÆ historiÆ doctissimi, et diligentissimi scriptores, Dionysius, et Livius. Quod attinet ad res, et tempora, Dionysii antefero diligentiam: verba a Livio malo repetere, et sententias. Neq[ue] enim minima historiÆ, ipsiusq[ue] iurisprudentiae RomanÆ pars, visq[ue] sita est in ipsis formulis; quas ubiq[ue] Livius diserte recitat, atq[ue] adeo religiose: Dionysius, et reliqui Graeci sua lingua exprimere non possent, ne si vellent quidem maxime. Unde Politicum decet, in primisq[ue] iurisconsultum, Livianae phrasis maxime omnium esse observantem: ut postea TaciteÆ. In qua RomanÆ prudentiÆ, et fortitudinis; temperantiÆ etiam, et iustitiae proprius quidam vigor, visq[ue] nervosa, vividius mihi videtur efflorescere, adeoq[ue] fertilius maturescere. Doctor Gentilis totus est Livianus: ut Lipsius fere Taciteus. Ambo sapiunt: sed uterq[ue] coniunctus, varieq[ue] coagmentatus plus valeret. TÆdet omnis sine varietate excellentiÆ: et philosophi est, plura bona paucioribus anteponere.

marginalia.translation: Yet the two most learned and assiduous writers of Roman history [are] Dionysius and Livy. In regard to the subject and the times I esteem Dionysius’ attentiveness more highly; I prefer to repeat the words and thoughts of Livy. For in these very formulas lies quite a big part of Roman history and of jurisprudence itself, which Livy recites dexterously and indeed religiously. Dionysius and the other Greeks could not have expressed them in their language, even if they had very much wanted to do so. And for this reason it is appropriate for the politician, and especially the jurisconsult, to be attentive most of all to Livy’s diction, just like afterwards to that of Tacitus. In this a particular vitality and powerful force of Roman prudence and courage, of restraint also and of justice seems to me to flourish in quite a lively way, and indeed to come to maturity in a very fruitful manner. Doctor Gentili is completely of Livy, just as Lipsius more or less of Tacitus. Both are wise, but each of them is stronger when connected and in various ways fastened together. Without variety every form of excellence makes weary, and it is the task of the philosopher to place a greater quantity of excellence before a smaller one.
